ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the medieval code of chivalry as it is portrayed in popular medieval literature and how chivalry has become a cultural fantasy that survived centuries, even today. The course material unraveling the history and development of chivalry was fascinating.
I have learned to structure and organize my thoughts in speaking/writing
This was a great medieval class, especially for those interested in having their worldview disrupted. It challenged my preconceived notions of chivalry and medieval thought.
I learned how to sift through lots of reading content and synthesize it in a way that I could talk about it in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The material of this course is so interesting. The background reading, secondary sources, and primary sources all worked really well together to allow us to have really fruitful discussions in class. Professor Ulrich is also so knowledgeable, and if there's any confusion on the history she always steps in to clear it up. Weakness: The reading is too long and dense. I enjoyed the readings, but it was frustrating that we regularly didn't have enough time in class to discuss all of them, even after I spent more than 6 hours reading a week.
No weaknesses, perfectly suited to student learning

I think the texts that we analyzed are the strength of this course. Everything we read provided something new to glean about chivalry and medieval literature. I think that discussions in the course were difficult to have remotely. I don't know why this class, in particular, was so difficult, but there was a disconnect between the students in this course. When this course is taught in person and there is able to be more camaraderie between the students and the professor, the course will improve.

I really enjoyed class discussions, especially since everyone was so committed to contributing. The workload, however, was a lotand sometimes I found myself engaging with the material less deeply in order to just have the time to get through it all.

This course was a decent amount of work and Professor Ulrich sets very high expectations. However, if you are a student interested in exploring new genres of literature, I highly recommend that you take this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had a regular seminar-style class, and I don't think it would have been different if we were in person.
This is by far the best class that I had over zoom this semester. I was always engaged and interested in the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although I loved this class, I would not recommend it to another student. It was so intensely time-consuming because there was so much reading, and we didn't even get to discuss all the reading in class because there was just too much. It was very interesting and I don't regret taking this classProfessor Ulrich and my classmates were all amazingbut I would tell another student to take another class with an equally interesting subject matter and less reading.
Yes-->You will develop both as a thinker, writer, speaker, and individual

If you are interested in the subject area or looking to fulfill the Medieval requirement for the English major, this is an excellent course to take. However, it requires a lot of commitment to get something out of the course. It's not a class to just skate through. If you're willing to commit, it's great.

Yes, but only if you are willing to put in the work when it comes to engaging with the material for this class. This is not the type of class that you can half-ass the reading and be okay. I loved this course, and if you have the time to commit to it, you will too!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a virtual seminar.

extras.title:
ENGL 140 01
        Chivalry, Power, and the Other
